intro: Voacanga grandifolia var. glabrifolia, commonly known as the African ivory tree, is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is native to tropical Africa. It is a deciduous tree that can grow up to 20 meters tall, characterized by its smooth, grayish bark and large, pinnate leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers followed by woody capsules containing elliptical seeds with a distinctive white aril. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine for their purported aphrodisiac and psychoactive properties. The tree also plays a role in local ecosystems and is sometimes cultivated for its ornamental value.
